video.title: Unity FPS Survival Game Tutorial - First Person Shooter Game Dev
video.description:
Learn how to make a first-person shooter in Unity.  Making a FPS in Unity is easy for beginners. This 8-hour tutorial covers everything you need to know to make a basic first person shooter game.

💻Assets: https://github.com/beaucarnes/unity_fps/tree/master/assets
💻Full Project: https://github.com/beaucarnes/unity_fps/tree/master/complete_project

Tutorial created by Awesome Tuts. Check out Awesome Tuts Youtube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5c-DuzPdH9iaWYdI0v0uzw

On the Awesome Tuts website, you can learn to create a game in 40 minutes: https://www.awesometuts.com/from-scratch-to-game-ws

The creator of the assets is Winterbyte and these are the assets from their Ultimate Survival Asset Pack. Please NOTE that these assets can be used only for EDUCATIONAL purposes to follow this tutorial, you can't use them to create a commercial game or share the assets with others.

⭐️Contents⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro And Game Preview
⌨️ (0:04:21) Importing Level And Configuring Lights In The Game
⌨️ (0:10:19) Creating FPS Player
⌨️ (0:35:35) Coding Player's Movement And Jump
⌨️ (1:02:07) FPS Mouse Look And Mouse Controls
⌨️ (1:33:14) Player's Sprint And Crouch
⌨️ (1:49:01) Player's Footsteps Sound
⌨️ (2:18:47) Animating Player's FPS Hands And Weapons
⌨️ (2:41:27) Weapon Handler (script for controlling the attributes of weapons)
⌨️ (2:57:05) Weapon Manager (script for controlling the switching between weapons in our game)
⌨️ (3:10:36) Player Attack (script for controlling the shooting with the selected weapon)
⌨️ (3:36:52) Creating The Zoom Effect With Animations And Scripting
⌨️ (4:07:02) Creating Arrow And Spear Bullet Prefabs
⌨️ (4:36:27) Configuring And Animating Our Cannibal Enemy
⌨️ (4:50:40) Creating Enemy Animation Script
⌨️ (4:57:30) Enemy Controller (the script that will control the enemy’s AI and make him move and attack the player)
⌨️ (5:40:04) Configuring And Creating The Boar Enemy
⌨️ (5:51:10) Detecting And Dealing Damage
⌨️ (6:14:52) Creating Health Script
⌨️ (6:49:02) Creating Player And Enemies Sound Effects And Shoot Effects Sounds
⌨️ (7:21:13) Creating Player Stats UI
⌨️ (7:32:38) Displaying Health And Stamina Using Player Stats UI
⌨️ (7:46:45) Creating Enemy Manager(the script that will spawn the enemies) and adding Finishing Touches To Our Game

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Braden Thornton
topLevelComment.text: If you are watching this in 2022, just a heads up, I recommend you change the code slightly in the Crouch function to ```if (Input.GetKeyDown(KeyCode.C) && character_Controller.isGrounded)``` so that your player cannot crouch while mid jump.  This prevents the player from crouching if they are mid jump!

topLevelComment.text: Did anyone have a problem with Cannibal raycasting and killing it? I think i have that because for some reason when i am doing animation from animation tab, my cannibal get position at around 0,0,0. Anyone has idea what do and how to fix that?

replies.author: DartFagnans
replies.text: on cannibal's rigidbody set useGravity = false (on the inspector). for some reason the rigidbody falls under the terrain, so raycast (or overlapsphere for the axe) can't detect the collision. then when cannibal dies you can set useGravity = true from the script before you "animate" his death

replies.author: Anna Izoutcheev
replies.text: @gaurav gupta First you must download all the files and folders from the "assets" directory on github. Save this "assets" folder somewhere on your computer (i.e, in "downloads"). Then create and open a new project, (don't import the new assets yet!) and close the project. Next, go to the downloaded assets folder, copy it and paste it to replace the project's existing assets folder. Finally, re-open your project.

topLevelComment.author: SLAYER NATION
topLevelComment.text: The best part was playing the game after building it. BTW I have few questions. One of them is if we use Time.deltaTime it will depend on players FPS right? won't his have unwanted speed issue on different devices?

replies.author: Wumpa
replies.text: No it will have the opposite effect. I.e. using that means their FPS won't change how it behaves. Because if they have a higher FPS the Time.deltaTime will be smaller, but there will be more of them. E.g. 20 FPS: Delta = 1/20 but it's called 20 times in a second so it's 1 per second. 10 FPS: Delta = 1/10 but it's only called 10 times in a second so it's 1 per second still (roughly). Hope that makes sense :)

topLevelComment.author: Will Forge
topLevelComment.text:
I need help with an issue... NEVERMIND! I fixed it almost 24 hours later (See my reply to this comment for details) Here is the original issue for anyone else running into the same thing:
When I play the game, the weapons don't appear on the screen. This started after I changed my FOV axis by accident. 
Before pressing play, if I view the "Game" window, the weapons appear on the screen, but when I load into the game they aren't visible. After pressing play, then ending the game to continue editing, the weapons suddenly stop being visible in the "Game" window as well. If I change anything in the Camera component of the FP Camera, then the weapons reappear, but again only in the "Game" window. They then disappear again when I hit Play.
This issue may be a bug from the newest version of Unity, or something, since the FOV axis option wasn't available in the version showed in this video. Or maybe it's something simple that I just don't understand. 
This is especially frustrating because I foolishly kept going through the tutorial. I'm now over 2 hours in, and was just starting on animating the weapons... but the animations are either not happening or are invisible when they do.

replies.author: Kristiyan Ivanov
replies.text: William Bosley The problem was that it wasn't linked. х)

replies.author: Will Forge
replies.text: @Kristiyan Ivanov did my solution not help?

replies.author: Kristiyan Ivanov
replies.text: My animations don't work, I checked everything...

replies.author: Will Forge
replies.text:
So it turns out that when you have multiple cameras, you need to force them to render in the correct order. This is the "Depth" field in the "Camera" component of each Camera object. The lower the number, the higher the priority of that camera. Since both of my cameras were set to 0, Unity had to decide which was on top, and I guess it chose the one tagged as "Main Camera". 
Now, in the video, Free Code Camp had his main camera set to -1. I don't know how mine wasn't, maybe it's defaulted to 0 after an update to Unity, or something. Or maybe I accidentally changed it? I don't know. Maybe I could start a new project just to see if it was default or my mistake, but I kinda don't care now that it's fixed. I left my main camera at 0, and put my FP Camera at 1. 
Problem solved. 
End of line.

topLevelComment.author: LightningParadox
topLevelComment.text: 01:05:00 what's the difference between declaring a public variable and a serialized private variable?

replies.author: LightningParadox
replies.text: @Daniel Corzo 👍🏼👌🏼

replies.author: Daniel Corzo
replies.text: @LightningParadox It's not going to affect performance or decrease the amount of FPS, but setting different levels of protection for your variables (this is, declaring them either public or private) prevents you or other programmers on a team to mess with the values of those variables when you're not supposed to, which could lead to bugs and/or undesired bahaviour.

replies.author: LightningParadox
replies.text: @Daniel Corzo thanks I got it. But is there any chance that having every variable as public affect game performance?

replies.author: Daniel Corzo
replies.text: Public variables can be accessed and modified from other classes (and you can also see them in the inspector), serialized private variables cannot be accessed or modified from other classes but they will pop up in the inspector so you can assign a value for them.
